chapter_title: Introduction to the Internet and World Wide Web

topics: Understanding the concept of the Internet as a global network of interconnected computers
Exploring the origin of the Internet (ARPANET and its initial purpose)
Discussing the growth and commercialization of the Internet in the 1990s
Describing the birth of the World Wide Web and Tim Berners-Lee’s contribution
Recognizing the impact of the first graphical web browser (Mosaic) on web accessibility
Identifying organizations that coordinate Internet standards (IETF, IAB) and governance
Differentiating private networks: intranets (internal networks) vs. extranets (secure external networks)
Understanding the role of the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) in developing and recommending web standards
Explaining what W3C Recommendations are and their influence on browser development and web design
Introducing the Web Accessibility Initiative (WAI) and the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)
Recognizing legal mandates for web accessibility (e.g., ADA and Section 508 requirements in the U.S.)
Defining the principle of universal design and its importance in inclusive web development
Identifying how accessible design practices improve usability for all users (including those on mobile devices)
Evaluating the credibility of online information (considering the source’s domain, authority, and purpose)
Assessing the timeliness of web content and the importance of up-to-date information on websites
Looking for references or external links on web pages as indicators of reliable, well-supported information
Using Wikipedia wisely as a starting point for research while verifying facts through cited references
Understanding ethical use of online content (avoiding plagiarism and unauthorized use of text, images, or designs)
Recognizing intellectual property rights on the Web and the purpose of Creative Commons licenses for sharing content
Defining a computer network and its purpose in enabling communication and resource sharing
Identifying common network components (server computers, client workstations, networking devices, and media)
Distinguishing between Local Area Networks (LANs) and Wide Area Networks (WANs) by scale and scope
Understanding the concept of a network backbone as a high-capacity link that interconnects multiple networks
Recognizing the Internet as a global network of networks, interconnected via high-speed backbone links
Explaining the client–server model as a relationship where a client requests services and a server fulfills those requests
Describing how clients and servers can be separate programs (often on different machines) communicating over a network
Illustrating a web scenario where a browser (client) requests a page and a web server responds with the requested resources
Comparing typical characteristics of web clients vs. web servers (e.g., intermittent use vs. continuous uptime)
Introducing Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) and their role in indicating the type of content being exchanged on the Web
Understanding that multiple communication protocols work together to enable Internet and Web functionality
Explaining File Transfer Protocol (FTP) and how it is used to exchange files between computers over the Internet
Identifying common e-mail protocols (SMTP for sending email; POP3/IMAP for retrieving email) and their roles
Describing how Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is used by web browsers and servers to exchange web pages and resources
Recognizing the importance of HTTPS for secure web communication by encrypting data between client and server
Understanding the role of the Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol (TCP/IP) suite as the foundation of Internet data transfer
Discussing the limitations of IPv4 addressing and the introduction of IPv6 to provide a vastly larger address space

lessons.lesson_title: Uniform Resource Identifiers and Domain Names
topics: Defining a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) as a unique address or identifier for a resource on the Internet
Differentiating a Uniform Resource Locator (URL) as a specific type of URI that provides the location of a web resource
Explaining the purpose of domain names as human-readable addresses that map to numerical IP addresses for websites
Introducing the Domain Name System (DNS) as the mechanism that translates domain names into their corresponding IP addresses
Recognizing common top-level domains (TLDs) such as .com, .org, .edu, and their general intended uses
Understanding Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML) as a system for defining structured document formats
Describing Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) as the standard language used to structure and present content on the Web
Explaining Extensible Markup Language (XML) as a flexible framework for defining custom data markup tags
Discussing Extensible Hypertext Markup Language (XHTML) as a stricter, XML-based reformulation of HTML for the Web
Highlighting HTML5 as the modern version of HTML that introduced new semantic elements and improved features
Exploring e-commerce as the buying and selling of goods and services online, and noting its ongoing growth in usage
Understanding mobile access to the Web and the rise of smartphones/tablets as common Internet devices
Recognizing blogs as frequently updated online journals and their value in communication and marketing
Identifying wikis as collaborative websites (e.g., Wikipedia) that users can edit to share knowledge collectively
Examining social networking platforms (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, etc.) and their widespread adoption for connecting people
Discussing cloud computing as the use of Internet-hosted services (storage, applications) and its definition by NIST as on-demand remote computing
Explaining Really Simple Syndication (RSS) as a format for delivering updated content (newsfeeds) from websites to subscribers
Describing podcasts as audio programs (like blogs in audio form or radio shows) available on the Web, often delivered via RSS feeds
Emphasizing the constant evolution of web technologies and the importance of continual learning to keep up with web trends
